newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore first quarter economic growth down.
newsitem.headline: Singapore first quarter economic growth down.

text.p: Singapore's economy grew by 3.8 percent in the first quarter of 1997, down from the previous quarter's 5.8 percent, the Trade Development Board (TDB) said on Friday.

The manufacturing sector remained weak while entrepot trade and shipping continued to be affected by the global slowdown in the electronics industry and slower regional growth, it said in a statement.
The slower first quarter growth compares with 5.8 percent in the fourth quarter and seven percent for the whole of 1996.
The TDB said, however, that electronics demand would improve in the later part of the year and that should keep the economy on a steady path toward recovery.
The Ministry of Trade and Industry retains its earlier growth forecast for 19977 of five to seven percent, it said.
Manufacturing, dampened by the cyclical slowdown in global demand for electronics, shrank by 6.7 percent after contracting by 0.7 percent in the previous quarter.
The TDB said that all major industries, with the exception of chemicals, declined during the first quarter this year.
Electronics growth fell 10.3 percent, against a drop of 2.3 percent a quarter earlier.
It said that apart from disk drives and telecommunications equipment, other segments of the industry, such as consumer electronics, personal computers and semiconductors, stayed weak.
Commerce sector growth slowed to 3.0 percent, down from 5.4 percent previously with entrepot trade hurt by slower regional growth and a retail industry hit by structural factors, it said.
But the financial and business sectors grew strongly by 10.5 percent, up from 10 percent in last quarter, the TDB said.
It said the financial services sub-sector benefitted from robust foreign exchange and Asian currency unit activity.
Business services also performed well, expanding by 8.4 percent on the back of growth in information technology.
In telecommunications, growth stablised at 7.6 percent, aided by the liberalisation of the paging and the communications markets on April 1.
The TDB also said that despite the cooling of the Singapore property market, construction growth remained healthy at 10.7 percent.
Contracts awarded in the first quarter fell by 1.6 percent to Singapore $3.7 billion, but public-sector residential demand kept construction robust, it said.
On employment, the TDB said that with the exception of manufacturing and commerce, all sectors saw an increase in jobs.
Labour remains tight. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in March was 1.8 percent against 1.9 percent in December.
But in line with weaker economic growth, overall labour productivity shrank by 1.7 percent in the first quarter.
--Singapore newsroom (65 8703080)
